Black Phoenix

This isn't exact but here's the basics I think are right:
 
 
 Evolutionists: We base our belief the Universe was formed 20 billion years ago. The Earth was formed 4.5 billion years ago. We speculate a rise in concentrated energy cause a massive explosion that resulted in millions of particles bumping into each other and eventually forming galaxies with in the universe, and planets with the galaxies. The planets, well one planet so far, managed to become inhabitable by life forms, that managed to survive and evolve over time. Admittedly we have some serious gaps and flaws here and there, but it's better than the mythological garbage of Zeus or any other God for that matter, creating the world. Mass can neither be created or destroyed. 
 
 Christian: God did it. (Then you could visit Dr. Hovind, or other creationists for some logic and reasoning)
 
 Of course both sides will say the other has fallible evidence.
 
 
 No matter what you'll never be able to convince the other side that they are wrong because you have the extraneous variable of faith......and faith being abstract and science being more of a physical nature is like saying oil is going to mix with water.
 
 So the ultimate answer comes down to your own convictions, knowledge, and experiences. Leaving the answer to the life long mystery as to "Why are we here?" up to the individual he or she must find the answer themself.

 Actually, you are misreprenting the scienctific answer in the following manner
 1) It is not evolutionists, it is astrophysicists.. 
 2) It is based on testable observations.. 
 3) Based on the available data, it is about 13.5 billion years old.
 4) It does not address the issue of 'Why we are here' at all. 
 5) It is not based on faith, but based on data. If data comes into change that evalutation, then by all means, it will be changed. This has happened a
 few times when it comes to cosmology. Our technology is good enough about gathering information it would probably take a real major discovery to change 
 things drastically at this point (but that would be fun)
 
 
 Although you claim that religion can do the same thing, that can not be demonstrated. You are also making the false claim that people who are religious can not accept science.. the only that that is different is that they don't take the stories in the bible literallyi, but only as an allegory.

Black Phoenix:
 
 We are all free to believe whatever we choose. The issue with regard to creationism vs. evolution is whether creationism should be taught in science classes in schools. From a scientist's point of view, creationism is not a scientific theory and should not be taught in science classes.
Mach

So the ultimate answer comes down to your own convictions, knowledge, and experiences. Leaving the answer to the life long mystery as to "Why are we here?" up to the individual he or she must find the answer themself.

 
 So the ultimate answer to whether or not the sun exists comes down to convictions. And you feel it's just as likely that it does exist, vs doesn't exist?
 
 If no, and you think it's more likely that the sun does indeed exist, then you're, I'm guessing here, ultimately contradicting yourself.
 
 Truth has nothing to do with conviction, to claim it does is unethical. If you killed my brother and you were completely and utterly convinced that he killed himself, I'm sorry Black Phoenix, you're not off the hook. How inhuman can one get!!?
 
 Yes, you should arrive at the answer yourself, but the answer about reality isn't dependant on your wishes or convictions.
 
 -Mach
doG

Evolutionists: We base our belief the Universe was formed 20 billion years ago. The Earth was formed 4.5 billion years ago. We speculate a rise in concentrated energy cause a massive explosion that resulted in millions of particles bumping into each other and eventually forming galaxies with in the universe, and planets with the galaxies. The planets, well one planet so far, managed to become inhabitable by life forms, that managed to survive and evolve over time. Admittedly we have some serious gaps and flaws here and there, but it's better than the mythological garbage of Zeus or any other God for that matter, creating the world. Mass can neither be created or destroyed.

 Evolution is not about how, why or when the universe formed;it is not about the beginning of life. Evolution is simply a theory that various types of animals and plants have their origin in other preexisting types and that the distinguishable differences are due to modifications in successive generations. That's all, nothing else. It is also just a theory and not an assumed postulate that solves all of our questions about life.
 
 A separate theory, the Big Bang Theory, posits that the universe as we know it was formed between 12 and 14 billion years ago. The 15-20 billion year numbers come predominantly from measurements of nearby and distant galaxies, particularly their rates of expansion away from us. Stellar evolution theory and observations of globular clusters (believed to contain the oldest stars in the galaxy) give estimates for the ages of the stars of 15-18 billion years. The distance scale measurements and big bang theory suggest the universe is 8-12 billion years old. Hence, either stellar evolution theory is incorrect, or how we measure distances is wrong. At any rate, these are just theories, not postulates, and we continue to make observations and predictions so that we may attempt to confirm or deny these theories in the spirit of science.
 
 
Christian: God did it. (Then you could visit Dr. Hovind, or other creationists for some logic and reasoning)

 A position born in times when man had less understanding of nature than he does now. There is no physical evidence to support or deny the existance of any supernatural entity. We do know that man has invented many gods to explain that which he does not know or understand through the course of time. At the same time, we have zero physical evidence to support the conclusion of any source as a first cause for existance so there is nothing wrong with some believing in a supernatural cause. It's not science but science has no proof of any cause either. Although we have no evidence to support such a cause, there is none that excludes it either.
 
 
Of course both sides will say the other has fallible evidence.

 It is not a both sides issue. Many philosophical ideologies have been proffered throughout time, not just two. There is no evidence to conclude that any of them exclude any of the others as possible answers to some of our questions.
 
 
No matter what you'll never be able to convince the other side that they are wrong because you have the extraneous variable of faith......and faith being abstract and science being more of a physical nature is like saying oil is going to mix with water.

 It is pointless to continue to attempt to prove that any side is wrong for the sole purpose of trying to shore up some other point of view. The ID camp does this regularly by trying to point out that evolution doesn't work for this or that. This only prove that evolution doesn't work for this or that and provides no support that ID is the solution for those questions. Every side should realize that even if they could disprove all other theories it would not prove that their own is right.
 
 
So the ultimate answer comes down to your own convictions, knowledge, and experiences. Leaving the answer to the life long mystery as to "Why are we here?" up to the individual he or she must find the answer themself.

 The ultimate answer most honest people should come to is that we have questions that we don't have answers for. We are looking for those answers. To leap to any conclusion without conclusive proof is an act of faith, not an answer. For questions like "Why are we here?" the individual should realize that there are some questions we may never have an answer for; it is pointless to invent answers for these questions.
Bud Light Man

 I see no reason why christianity and faith can't mix. I am an athiest, but I see it every day. There are many, many, christians who believe that the bible is not literal, but believe god made the big bang to bring forth matter and the laws of physics which govern out universe. He then left it to go as he planned.
 
 This is the only blending of science and faith that I can stand, as we don't know were the big bang came from. So, I am quite happy for people to fill that "gap" with faith.
 
 Then you have YECs. We all know what they are like.

I see no reason why christianity and faith can't mix. I am an athiest, but I see it every day.  Seeing that there are indeed people who believe in both, has no impact on whether or not beliving in both is contradictory or not. Indeed, if you pushed them all the way to their philosophical underpinnings, you'd necessarily find contradictions between reason, and faith. They are opposites, like true and false.
 
 Blending "science" with faith, isn't a blending of systems of belief. Science is put simply, knowledge. Yes, every capable human has some knowledge about reality, but may or may not also make up their own reality (religion). Science itself is not a way of thinking, it's just a body of knowledge. Most religious people acknowledge that if they don't turn at an intersection then they'll probably run off the road. However, if they applied the same reasoning that they arrived at that knowledge with, to faith/myths, they'd have to reject them. So no, reason and faith are mutually exclusive. The empirical methods of science have no comment on faith-based myths, not because they cannot go there, but because there is nothing to test in the first place.
 
 -Mach

Scientist Albert Einstein would disagree with you. He said, "Science without Religion is lame, Religion without Science is blind". 

 It is also important to notice the context of this remark:
 

 "To this there also belongs the faith in the possibility that the regulations valid for the world of existence are rational, that is, comprehensible to reason. I cannot conceive of a genuine scientist without that profound faith. The situation may be expressed by an image: science without religion is lame, religion without science is blind."
 

 It was not a usage about religious faith in any god, but faith that the laws of nature are reasonable. In that remark he was simply using religion as an alternate term for faith, not spirituality.
